title: Unit Fraction Sum
content: The sum of unit fractions 1/n over a finite set S. This is the core object of study - we want to find subsets where this sum equals a 'simple' rational.

title: α-Dense Subset
content: A set A is α-dense in {1,...,N} if it contains at least αN elements. This density condition is the key hypothesis - we need A to be 'large enough' relative to N.

title: Simple Rational
content: A rational a/b is 'simple' with bound B if a ≤ b (so it's at most 1) and the denominator b ≤ B. The goal is to find such rationals as unit fraction sums.

title: Bound Function
content: The bound on denominators depends on α: B(α) = ⌈exp(1/α)⌉. This captures the 'O_α(1)' in Erdős's statement - the bound depends only on α, not on N.

title: Erdős #310 Conjecture
content: The original conjecture: for any α > 0 and N ≥ 1, if A is α-dense in {1,...,N}, then A contains a subset with a simple unit fraction sum. This asks whether density alone guarantees 'rich' structure.

title: Bloom's Theorem (2021)
content: Bloom proved that dense sets contain subsets whose unit fraction sum is close to 1 (within 1/2). This is the key ingredient - it guarantees a sum in the interval [1/2, 3/2].

title: Bloom Implies Rational Bound
content: Bloom's theorem immediately gives us a subset with sum in [1/2, 3/2]. Any such rational has denominator at most 2 (in lowest terms), which is quite simple!

title: Liu-Sawhney Theorem (2024)
content: The precise quantitative version: for (log N)^{-1/7} ≤ α ≤ 1/2, there exists S with a/b = Σ 1/n where b ≤ exp(10/α). This gives explicit control over the denominator.

title: Sharpness of Bound
content: The exponential dependence exp(O(1/α)) cannot be improved. For any constant C, there exist examples where the minimum denominator exceeds exp(C/α). This shows the result is optimal.

title: Main Result: Erdős #310 Solved
content: The main theorem asserting that the answer to Erdős #310 is YES. Every α-dense set contains a subset with simple unit fraction sum, where 'simple' means denominator at most exp(O(1/α)).

title: The Answer is YES
content: The final answer: Erdős's conjecture is true. This theorem states that for all α > 0, the conjecture erdos_310_conjecture α holds.

title: Simple Example: 1/2
content: The simplest example: S = {2} gives unitFractionSum = 1/2, which is a simple rational. This shows the definition works as expected.

title: Classic Example: 1/2 + 1/3 + 1/6 = 1
content: The famous Egyptian fraction identity: 1/2 + 1/3 + 1/6 = 1. This shows that 1 can be written as a sum of three distinct unit fractions - a result known since antiquity.

title: Egyptian Fraction
content: An Egyptian fraction representation is a sum of distinct unit fractions. The ancient Egyptians used this system exclusively for representing fractions.

title: Every Positive Rational is Egyptian
content: A classical result: every positive rational can be written as a sum of distinct unit fractions. This is not directly related to #310 but provides important context.
